reviewText:
Beautiful, tranquil, and disappointingly buggy.

I was really looking forward to this game. I've played all kinds of MMOs, and one focused on pure exploration sounded like a lot of fun. This game makes an admirable attempt at delivering that, but there are too many immersion breaking bugs to really enjoy it.

I love the way the game looks. I like the lack of a HUD. I'm fine with no combat, no quests, no loot, etc. Call it a multiplayer walking simulator if you like, but I think the no pressure approach is an enjoyable break from the addictive grinding of the typical WoW-style game. There's great potential here.

Unfortunately, I've encountered a number of bugs in the brief time I've played that have hampered my enjoyment. After logging out and then returning, I'm now stuck in third-person view instead of first person. The graphics settings reverted to default too. There's a distracting amount of texture pop-in. Movement is clunky. The controls are unclear, and aren't shown anywhere (which means no keybind settings either). But the worst was trying to use the language drawing.

You see, the only way you have of communicating with other players is by drawing word pictures. There are stones throughout the game that teach you how to draw the words, including the order of the strokes, which matters for getting the word right. Precision matters too, making it easy to get the words wrong. Worse, on the third word I found (near")
date: I couldn't get it right until I figured out that the stone was showing the strokes in the wrong order!\n\nSo
hoursPlayed: that's my first impressions review. Hopefully they patch this stuff soon
voteText: because I think this could be a great game. For now
helpfulPercent: I'll try it a little bit longer to see if it grows on me
votesHelpful: but I can't in good conscience recommend it.\n\nEdit: After giving it more thought
votesTotal: I decided to ask for a refund for this game (which has been granted). The unfortunate day-one experience left a bad taste in my mouth
votesFunny: and as a result I don't have any enthusiasm for sticking with this through the bug-fix process."

reviewText:
The Wander team is painfully kind, works tirelessly with the community, and is full of creative potential - unfortunately, at this point, I cannot recommend Wander.

Wander appears to be an experiement in deconstructing an MMO. What if we took away chat, levels, killing things, and quests? What would we be left with? How would players communicate? What would they do? It's actually a really neat idea and I'm glad someone conducted the experiment. In ideal play, you would run into other players and use an in-game sign language to communicate what you would like to do including some tricky achievements.

Instead of a list of pros and cons, I'll just post a list of hopes:

Hopes for the Devs:
Stay encouraged and now that you've built a game and released it to market - think about what you can do better and put out an awesome next game. Y'all have some serious talent when it comes to graphics, voice overs, and atmosphere.
Lower the price to free or just above free. Nobody should be paying the same for this game and ARK
I suspect y'all are millenials. Hire a Gen-X or Baby Boomer to round out your team. They will point out the blind spots.
Think about adding in what you've taken out (chat, quests, killing, etc) but in a special way that stays true to your vision. Reconstructing what has been deconstructed.
Go 100% into VR. Whether on HTC Vive or Oculus Rift - huge potential here!
I'm cheering for you. Rooting for you. Love the glimpse of talent. I'm looking forward to writing a positive review on your next game.

reviewText:
There are games that are bad, and there are games that are heart wrenchingly disappointing. Wander wasn't just a swing in the dark for a quick cash grab, it was a notion with all of the conceptual dominoes ready to be knocked down. An MMO with a focus on environment and exploration as opposed to combat. They say that when someone loses their sight, all of their other senses get stronger. That isn't the case with Wander. It's as if they made an MMO with a world, NPCs, and combat, then just removed the NPCs and combat and called it a day. There was so many opportunities to make this game an interesting piece of work without the crutch of combat and violence, that were also thrown away at every turn.

Every building is empty. Nothing worth noting. Imagine this game where there is a sprawling population, people to meet and to go on quests with. This doesn't demand the idea of combat, it just demands the idea of objective. Wander is based on a safari jungle, so why not have an encyclopedia worth of animals to discover and watch? An incredible depth of species and organisms to research. Wander could have had that and much more, but instead it doesn't have much of anything.

You cannot directly communicate with players. Wander has its own language, Rozdha, which can be learned by coming across stones that teach you one word at a time. To have a real conversation with a fellow player, you would have both needed to spend countless hours learning and remembering these words. There is no encyclopedia, so if you're not recording the notions yourself, good luck. It would've been great if there were ways to communicate with other players, but Rozhda could be used to access hidden or specific content. That'd be great because it'd influence exploration and flesh the world and objectives out a bit.

Wander is underdeveloped. Bugs litter the game, and texture popping happens more than appreciated with it being a visually-focused game. Even without the bugs, the previous reasons are why this game truly falters.

Our medium is interesting. There is a thriving mobile market based on the idea of copying others to make a quick buck. Yet, that's not Wander did. They cropped up a simply amazing concept, with the potential of excellence, and dropped it like an egg. I personally hope they either revert this game into early access, or someone takes their idea and fleshes it out like it deserves.


Here is a video review from me if you're interested in seeing more: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0YMgecmdNT4

reviewText: The game *looks* good, all the Kudos to the world designers and of course CryEngine. You need proper application developers though as well: within the first 7 minutes I played Wander, I was greeted with graphical errors, spazzing out triggers, sound settings not being applied, no sub titles (okay, design problem) and finally a crash when I tried to quit the game. Suffice to say that this is not within the bounds I'd remotely consider acceptable.

reviewText:
I don't really know where to start on this. People say it's terrible because of its bugs but in all honesty, it's a game still being worked on as I write this review. The developers are one of the most dedicated game devs I have ever seen and are devoted to satisfying their customers, hearing out what people have to say and most importantly they care about what me and others as individuals have to say about the game so long as it isn't childish bashing like i've seen most of the negative reviews based on with a few decent ones mixed in.

Pros of Wander:
-Stunning atmosphere, really makes you feel immersed in the game
-Its constantly being updated
-Neat lore and a different gamestyle which is unique and stays true to the name Wander in the gameplay
-Not many goals, you just sit back, relax and enjoy the scenery and the game
-You can be four characters, all of which are well programmed into the game
-Neat and realistic sound affects
-Developers listen to the community
-Many different sceneries to wander to such as a floating island, the bottom of the ocean and the oceanic runes, the caves and the cultural tribe areas
-Each character has it's own environments and differences from the others
-Relaxing open world game for those who get tired of games that have so much going on in them that makes it stressful and Wander has so much content with so little guidelines that you do whatever you want when you want.
-Has multiplayer so you can wander with other people
-Has neat loading in soundtracks

Cons of Wander:
-Characters lack landscape centering. (Ex: Climbing a hill as an Azertash will have your back feet in the air like so.
-Has its fair share of bugs as does any game.
-Lacking a few textures in some areas in the terrain
-Griffin has too slow of a dive speed and too slow of an upward flight
-Oren's tree branches take up too much of the screen
-Difficult to find other players
-Textures take too long to load into view

All in all it's got cons to match the pros, but I just wanted to say that for some people this game is for you, and for others you may prefer your shooter games. It depends on what you like and if you're open to trying out new things. I'd recommend this game just because it really is stunning to enjoy a slow paced game with lots to offer. If you have an issue with a bug, you can make a topic on it and I guarantee you that someone, if not the Wander team themself will answer it and will look towards fixing the bug. It's costly, but for good reason. It's the perfect game for you if every game you play is either frustrating, painstakingly boring or if you like what you've seen on the store page. It's different, yes but in a good way. This has my vote.

reviewText:

Reasons why you should not spend $25 on this game:
It's an MMO with nobody else playing.
It said to follow the operatic singing that I never heard.
Exploration game with a 3rd person view character that takes up half the screen and moves slower than a turtle.

reviewText:
The good

The game oozes tranquillity and chillness.
Some very nice vistas that make good use of the Cryengine tech.
Interesting gameplay idea
The not so good:
Clunky character movement - your characters slide on the ground and this really takes you out of the fantasy.
A ♥♥♥♥♥♥me lives and dies with its community - there was no sign of anyone in the game and the devs didn’t implement any tools for players to find eachother faster. (I know there’s the whole exploring part, but for new players it just seems like a barren and boring land)
If you don’t go up at the first intersection, you’ll be stuck as a tree for like 2 hours, until you manage to crawl towards a transforming stone. It was very frustrating.
The conclusion:
In this fast paced, dog eat dog world, it’s nice that someone tried to imagine a game where everything is slow and relaxing. Unfortunately, this is not supposed to be a screensaver, it’s supposed to be a game. And gameplay in Wander is scarcer than water in Mad Max. Empty servers, empty world...for a 20 euro game, it’s fails to deliver on the promise it makes. If you want to save yourself 20 euros, google some nature sounds, put your headphones on, close your eyes and meditate for an hour. It’ll be more enjoyable than Wander is.

You can see me playing here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dM6r-nC0u7k
voteText: 21 of 26 people (81%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Wander is a beautiful game with lots of potential. Right from the beginning I was consumed by the game. It is so beautiful and well designed. Your eyes will constantly look around at this beautiful world. Also the 'creatures' are quite wonderful as well, much detail was given to them. In this open world, the game has a very simple objective. Explore. Spend hours searching the islands for caves, lore stones, and also wander around to discover the language of this majestic world.

Even after a few months of pain stakingly fixing bugs and such the game still has a few. It's not that bad, but the devs are still very active in this game. They give you a lot of their time, spending the day answering questions and most-likely fixing the bugs that still exist in this game. The bugs aren't major things, sometimes the game won't load or you can't ride a Griffin, but eventually these things do work, though I haven't had much luck on riding a Griffin.

Oh yes, in this game you can because four 'creatures' which are named; Orin, Griffin, Hira, and Azertash. The Orin form is basically you are a tree. It's some what annoying because your branches tend to cover the entire screen so soon you will want to change forms into something more agile and quick. That form would be the Hira form, which is essentially human form. Third form is the Griffin. So with this form you can fly, you are part hawk, part lion/tiger/leopard (Depending on what rock you use to change into this form). It is amazing to fly above the massive world you can explore, also in this form you can fly to the floating island that levitates in the sky with an amazing waterfall crashing down off of it. The last form is the Azertash which in short is basically a 'water dragon.' It swims in the water with great speed and you can explore the depths of the ocean. It is quite amazing being at the bottom of the ocean, though I wish more effort was put into the folliage down in the depths.

With these four forms you can explore the world like you've never known. Being able to fly to the heavens or to the depths of the sea. Or you can explore the islands to find hidden caves and secrets. This game is truly beautiful and the great news is that a new update will be out soon.

In conclusion, if you are someone who enjoys open world, exploration and relaxing games this is something you should look into. I myself do not like stressful games and this one I could play for hours, wandering around aimlessly and taking in this breathless world that I know so little about. It will shock you when you have seemed to explore the whole island that you find something new. The world is huge, and very detailed. So in the end I would definitively Recommend this game.

reviewText:
Great concept, however feels unfinished. Missing textures in cave and in global map. Forced antialiasing strains hardware a lot. Unless users are equipped with beastly machine, higher resolutions and settings doesn't make much sense.
It's somewhat playable on 1024x768 high on HD7750 and 800x600 low on Intel HD4000.

Graphics looks pretty, but not so pretty to justify such graphics requirements. Skyrim with 2K textures looks a bit better and still pose no problems to my integrated HD4000, running at 25-40fps high and 720p resolution. Wander on the other hand, as previously mentioned, 800x600 low.

At this time game not quite ready. Now I'm in two minds whether to request refund or just wait for fix and if possible, optimization, so that all of us, regardless of how powerful are our HW, can enjoy the game..
I'm going to click no" this time
date: but happily change my vote to 'yes' once things start to improve.\n\nKeeping my fingers crossed for you. ;)"

reviewText:
You have to be willing to be patient with this game. It is a slow, contemplative experience. Take your time, explore and enjoy the sense of a spiritual journey.

It may be a little glitchy, and the practically absent interface can be a bit confusing, but for lovers of exploration and puzzle-solving, these are not insurmountable barriers.

After working through the initial frustrations, my first 4 hours with this game were an entrancing experience and already worth the price of admission.

reviewText: From the short period of time I devoted to playing this game I can confidently give it a thumbs down. The introduction to the game was terribly poor, the animations are lacking, and there are numerous bugs still lying about. The option menu didn't even work! Game mechanics, such as writing symbols, were not nearly explained enough tfor me to understand the first part of it and what constitutes a success and a failure. reviewText:
Author's Note: This game is, essentially, in late alpha/early beta. Glitch, bugs, and errors can and DO occur. If you forget this and buy it and start complaining that the game is buggy, well. . .who's fault is that?

-----------------------

ATTENTION VIEWER!

Do you want a game where you have to deal with 'levels' and 'fetch quests'? What about dealing with people whining that the game is 'pay to win' or 'bots are everywhere'? Do you like playing the same type of cookie cutter gameplay over and over again? Hotbars, gear stats, cooldowns, and all those hot staples of the early MMO genre?

If you answered yes to any or all of these things, you can just leave the room right now because this game is NOT for you!

Now, if you've come this far you are either: A) Not interested in the standard 'MMO' type game or B) you like those games but don't like playing five billion of them that are essentially the same.

-----------------------

The sole premise of 'Wander' is right there in the name: You wander. You amble. You roam. you don't have to deal with pointless quests, mobs, and all that junk. It's just you and the vibrant, diverse terrain. You start out as an Oren, a tree creature, but can gain three more forms to change into:

- The Hira is the first you will likely get: a female humanoid with fins on the back of the arms and legs which can act as a wingsuit while falling. The Hira moves and swims rather fast.

- The griffin, which can fly. Flight mechanics feel right and realistic but require practice to get the handle of. You can spot thermals with LMB to see where you can get some extra lift or descend faster.

- The- uh. . .lizard thing with the really long tail. Slow on land, but fast in the water.

-----------------------

Now, if you enter the game and find it feeling lifeless, that's because there are no NPCs. Only players. But there are not many players so you will often find yourself wandering alone and lost. . .but don't worry, ol' Bubbles here is gonna help you out. People can usually be found on that big ol' floating island, along the beaches, or near the strikingly obvious landmarks. Hira players can climb onto the backs of griffins to get a lift around, and can also jump off their avian friends to skydive, performing tricks and perhaps either landing in the water or on the back of the same or another griffin.

-----------------------

You cannot communicate with a microphone or with text chat. Instead, you can communicate universally through drawn glyphs that allow your character to speak certain phrase of the custom language made for the game. The controls for this are difficult. You are required to draw on the screen (using your mouse, silly!)  the symbol you wish for your character to say. . .of course, there's then the problem on if you can remember the words themselves, requiring you to practice drawing and listening to the words so you can  understand other people.

-----------------------

The game undeniably needs tweaking and fixing, but the core aspects of the game are wonderful for those people who like to take in exotic, fantastical scenery in a game world that does not spoonfeed the player the world's story. . .so go out there and explore- or, dare I say it- Wander!

reviewText:
This game is visually amazing. The atmosphere of the game is amazing and draws you in.

The Dev team work tirelessly to get updates out for the game, fixing problems that arise, adding in new features and taking community feedback on board.

The problem with the game though, is that it is a niche game. It wont appeal to everyone.

The gameplay is exactly like the name of the game, you Wander around the game and explore. You learn about the lore of the world by finding Lorestones. You learn the language by finding and discovering Rhozda stones. You can transform to 1 of 4 different characters by finding Transform stones which then let you change at will by using the LoreCave. With more versions of them being added, currently there are 2 different types of Griffin.

This game is perfect for relaxing and enjoying the atmosphere. Would be 90000 times better if/when VR Support and 1st person view is added in. But for now, we need to make do with what is there.

Highly enjoy the game and i highly recommend it to anyone that this game appeals to. If you think it would be boring, dont get it, as its not the kind of game you would most likely like.
voteText: 17 of 49 people (35%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Wander isn't for everyone.  If you are into goals, tasks, collecting trophies - go somewhere else.

If you enjoy walking along beautiful pathways, discovering waterfalls, ruins, learning about a culture that you may now be a part of, swimming below the oceans, flying over peaks, exploring caves and more, this game will suit you fine.

It's the most lush and pretty game I've ever played and I've really enjoyed discovering some of the little things, like the frogs in one of the ponds or seeing a bird fly overhead.   There are a lot of varied sounds of birds and insects along with scurrying things in the underbrush or bats in the caves.

As one of the testers, I've seen the game evolve as the small team building it tried out different ideas and then spent a big amount of time having to change to another platform.   It was worth the wait.

Are there problems with it - yes, of course.  It's only been live to the public for four days.   What the heck do some of these people expect?   But the team (of about 10 now) have been working day and night trying to fix and upgrade the issues that have up and the fact that people play the game for .01 and then give it a thumbs down in the reviews is ridiculous.

If you are interested in this game, give the team a chance to work out the bugs and add new features to help players enjoy the game more (the new dictionary was installed today).

If you truly want an relaxing game that is interesting and intriging, give Wander a try.   And I hope to see you there.

reviewText:
It's a game in the same way that Minecraft is a game, although there is at this point no building and no plans for it.

If you want quests or fighting, this is not the game for you. If you want a completely polished AAA experience with no bugs or problems of any kind, this is not your game. The game is effectively in beta, and features exploring, enjoying the very rich and beautiful world, with a little culture shock along the way.

There are Lore Stones and Conversation Stones to listen to, and there is a dictionary for the in-game language. There's currently four shapes all players can transform into, but you have to find the other three stones that enable those additional shapes. The entire environment is hand-built, and no two places are identical.

This game (as of this writing) has been out only four days. Note the amount of time people have been playing before giving their reviews. It's hilarious, the way people have been jumping into this game and expecting a Quest-driven NPC dense game filled with a lundry list of things to do and places to visit. This just shows how much like Skinner Boxes recent games have become with everyone complaining about not being able to find the lever that would give them their treat.

If you want a truly relaxing game with an interesting history and gorgeous graphics, this is your game. If not, you might want to keep your distance until you get tired of pulling levers in other people's cookie cutter games.

reviewText:
This game is pretty fun. As it's a noncombative mmo, I think half the fun is figuring out the language in the game along with the controls instead of them being readily delivered to the player. The game places strong emphasis on finding things. There are stones littered around the map with words that the player can learn in order to interact with other people. Players can also select one of four forms to further their explorations. Interestingly, players must find these forms first :)

Pros:

. Interesting concept
. Information about the world unfolds as you explore
. Unique way of gaining forms by finding them
. plenty of amazing places to hang out and meet people
. plenty of places to explore
. Unique language development
. Gorgeous music and landscape
. Nonviolent
. No levels
. No currency
. No item level


Cons:

. No ability to talk" to other plays unless you learn the language (which is also a pro
date:
as it  makes the game unique)
. No ability to make permanent friends (no friendslist)
. No ability to differentiate players from one another (everyone has same models/no playernames)
. Graphics are a bit buggy at times
. Controls are a bit difficult to figure out at first (but rewarding once you do)


Conclusion:

The game is pretty fun as the player "Wanders" around learning the language

reviewText:
I've been playing for 2 hours and just found the place where I can transform.  I love this type of game and enjoyed wandering around, even though the tree is difficult to see through sometimes.  I have a pretty decent PC with the settings way up high for graphics and resolution. I think there are a few glitches but none of them affect my enjoyment of the game.  I want to relax and wander and that's what I'm getting.  I get to figure things out, but there is no time limit and I'm not gonna die if I don't get to a certain 'level' in time.  Srsly, my dream game.

So far, this game is delivering most of what it promised.  I'm sure the developers will update to address the small glitches, but anyone who is looking for a fast pace will not like this game.  There are games out there that are also exploration games but have defined goals.  I like those too, but this is not like that, as far as I can tell.

Pro:
no violence
graphics beautiful
relaxing sounds
narrator is pleasant sounding
beautiful scenery to wander
sounds are important to knowing where you are
huge area to explore

Con:
i don't know yet

I know some people will think the Pro list is boring, but to me, it is just what I'm looking for.  There are plenty of games out there to get your blood pumping and precious few that do the opposite.  I definitely recommend.

reviewText: Beautiful and tranquil game! Bit of a slow haul at the beginning but that is just a part of the journey. reviewText:
To start: this is not a game like you've ever played before.

It's a wonderfully immersive visually beautiful environment, where the only characters mechanics are chaning forms, there is no combat system, no direct way to communicate in your native language, or task based questing system.

This game for me is a meditative exercise, I find I can just exhale, walk, and discover in this game, if you're looking for an average MMO, this is not the game for you!

Additional notes:
This game probably should have been released in early access" it lacks a certain polish

reviewText:
TLDR: This is a stunningly beautiful game, with some initial release bugs that are already being ironed out, highly recommend!

So I just installed wander earlier. I've read the reviews but i've been waiting for this title for a while so decided to give it a go myself first before passing judgment. All I can say is, the developers must have been super fast in cleaning up the bugs people have been talking about because apart from some pollishing up the game killer bugs people are talking about don't seem to be there anymore.

The game environment is beautiful, though there are bugs they are obviously things that are going to be improved in the near future. The exploratory gameplay mechanic is something i've been waiting for, this is basically an MMO adventure game were we come together to solve the puzzle of what is going on in this universe. This is a game for people who want to solve a mystery, for people who like turning the page of a story one puzzle solve at a time (puzzle being finding the hints). I get the sense there is actually a big story waiting to be unravelled.

The one game mechanic i don't like is a lack of voice chat between players, communicating with the in game gestures seems like a cool idea but doesn't really work on a practical level. I'm hoping that is something they sort out, otherwise it will end up probably being a big persistant single player game with people running past each other :P.

I am running the game on high quality and I have a first gen I7, 6 gig of ram, and a radeon r9 - 270x

Can't wait to see how the story turns out and hopefully some more bug fixing :P
